I would imagine that when a rich man does not spend money on saving the lives of others, he might find it hard to justify his choices at the pearly gates.
 
 "So, why did you buy four new cars over your life, but not donate a similar amount of money to the red cross?"
 
 I mean, when it's a choice between buying pet food, or donating canned food to the Salvation army, I can't see how one could justify buying pet food as a religiously moral choice. The same applies to buying a new computer instead of flying to india to help build a school, or putting your kids through college instead of buying polio vaccine to be distributed in africa.
 
 When a person has disposable income, and another person somewhere in the world is starving to death, or dieing from an easily preventable disease like Typhoid or Polio, then the person who has that disposable income is at least partially responsible for those deaths. He could have spent that extra money on vaccines, training, flights, agricultural development, education, whatever. But he chose not to, and as a result, those things were not purchased and those lives were not saved. This applies moreso to those who have more disposable income, because they can save more lives with less personal sacrifice. Bill Gates could donate forty billion dollars, and still have as many assets and as much income as middle America. It isn't the sole responsibility of the rich to care for anyone, but they can do more, and sacrifice less, than others. Which makes it much harder to justify their choice to NOT do it.

I believe that what is actually said in the Bible about wealth is that "the love of money is the root to all evil." I think the main idea is to not let money be the main drive in your life. How much money you have is not as important than what you do with it. There is a passage where Jesus commends a widow for putting in the only coins (2 copper coins) she had for offering while all that was being put in by anyone else was a mere 3 or 4 gold coins out of their stock piles. She gave 100% of what she had while the others were giving maybe 10% of what they had (which I believe is the customary thing to do) to show off how much they were putting in. But through out the Bible, their is more favor put upon the people who put their faith higher than there money.
 Now one could argue that Jesus was a communist (if that party was around in 30 A.D.) He compared the kingdom of Heaven with a guy who owned a vineyard and wanted workers to come work for him. As the day progressed, more workers came and then at the end of the day, the owner gave them each the same amount. (Now, isn't that a communist thing?) The workers represented people who came to believe in Jesus and the owner represented God. The day that they worked represented life and the night represented death and their equal wages represented their acceptance into Heaven no matter how late in life they became a believer, which is what the time they came to work for represented.
 That's my own commentary, and I could be wrong. But as others have said, I don't think it is as much based upon wealth as it is on faith.
